transcript:
Patient: I've been trying to practice self-compassion, but it's hard. I keep falling back into old patterns of self-criticism.

Therapist: I understand, Jamie. Developing self-compassion is a process, and it's common to face challenges along the way. Let's explore this further. Can you give me an example of a situation where you struggled with self-compassion?

Patient: Well, the other day I was running late for work because I overslept. I immediately started berating myself, thinking things like, "You're so lazy and irresponsible. You can't even get to work on time."

Therapist: That's a great example, Jamie. Let's break this down using the CBT triangle. The situation was running late for work. The emotions you felt were probably frustration and self-directed anger. And the thoughts were, "You're so lazy and irresponsible. You can't even get to work on time." Is that accurate?

Patient: Yes, that sums it up pretty well.

Therapist: Okay, now let's try to reframe those thoughts using a more compassionate lens. First, let's consider the evidence. Have you been consistently late for work, or was this a one-time occurrence?

Patient: It was just this one time. I'm usually very punctual.

Therapist: That's important to recognize, Jamie. Everyone has off days, and it doesn't mean you're lazy or irresponsible. Now, let's consider what you would say to a friend who was in the same situation. Would you tell them they were lazy and irresponsible?

Patient: No, of course not. I would probably tell them not to be so hard on themselves and that everyone makes mistakes.

Therapist: Exactly, Jamie. And that's the kind of compassion we want to extend to ourselves as well. So, let's reframe those self-critical thoughts. Instead of saying, "You're so lazy and irresponsible," what could you say to yourself?

Patient: I guess I could say something like, "It's okay. Everyone has off days. I'll try to get to bed earlier tonight so I can be on time tomorrow."

Therapist: That's a great reframe, Jamie! It acknowledges the situation without being self-critical and focuses on a solution for the future. How does that feel compared to the original self-critical thoughts?

Patient: It feels a lot better. I still feel a bit guilty for being late, but I don't feel as ashamed or angry at myself.

Therapist: That's wonderful, Jamie. That's the power of self-compassion. It allows us to acknowledge our mistakes without getting stuck in self-criticism. As we continue to practice this, it will become easier to extend compassion to yourself in challenging moments.

Patient: I hope so. It's just hard to break the habit of self-criticism.

Therapist: I understand, Jamie. It's a process, and it takes time. That's why we'll continue to practice self-compassion in our sessions and in your daily life. Speaking of practice, let's discuss some ways you can incorporate self-compassion into your routine. One technique is to create a self-compassion mantra or affirmation that you can repeat to yourself when you're feeling self-critical. What might a compassionate affirmation look like for you?

Patient: Hmm, maybe something like, "I am human, and I am allowed to make mistakes. My worth is not defined by my perfection."

Therapist: That's a beautiful affirmation, Jamie. It acknowledges your humanity and separates your self-worth from perfectionism. I encourage you to write that down and repeat it to yourself whenever you notice self-critical thoughts arising.

Patient: I'll definitely try that. Thank you.

Therapist: You're welcome, Jamie. Remember, developing self-compassion is a skill, and it takes practice. Be patient with yourself as you work on this. In addition to the affirmation, another technique is to practice self-care. Engaging in activities that nourish your mind and body can help cultivate self-compassion. What are some self-care activities you enjoy?

Patient: I love taking baths, reading, and going for walks in nature.

Therapist: Those are all wonderful self-care activities, Jamie. I encourage you to make time for them regularly, especially when you're feeling self-critical. Engaging in self-care can help shift your focus from self-criticism to self-nurturing.

Patient: I'll try to make more time for self-care. It's just hard sometimes with work and other responsibilities.

Therapist: I understand, Jamie. It can be challenging to prioritize self-care when life gets busy. That's why it's important to schedule it into your routine, just like any other commitment. Even small acts of self-care, like taking a few deep breaths or enjoying a cup of tea, can make a difference.

Patient: That's a good point. I can start small and build up from there.

Therapist: Absolutely, Jamie. Every act of self-compassion, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction. As we continue to work on this together, you'll find it easier to extend compassion to yourself in all areas of your life.

Patient: I'm looking forward to that. Thank you for your support and guidance.
